caption: Pastor and Gospel Singer Don Moen Dead After a Short Illness

candidates.title: Is Pastor and Gospel Singer Don Moen Dead After a Short Illness?
candidates.content:
Claim:
In July 2017, Don Moen died of "stomach pain".
On 12 July 2017, the HoustonChronicle-TV web site published an entirely fake story, reporting that American gospel singer and pastor Don Moen had died after a "short illness":
American singer-songwriter, Evangelist Don Moen has died after [a] short battle with stomach pain. His family confirmed that he died early this morning at General Acute Care (GAC) Hospital in California barely [a] couple of hours after he was rushed to the hospital.
The article is riddled with errors and fabrications, such as California's "General Acute Care Hospital", which does not exist, and a fake tribute from President Donald Trump. Moen's collaborator — Nigerian Christian Contemporary music artist Frank Edwards — confirmed the report is a hoax, tweeting a screenshot of a text message sent by Moen's son Michael, who wrote:
Dad is great and it good health. That article is false and just trying to get people to click thru [sic] to their website. I'll have dad post something on social media shortly so people know.
On the day the fake article was published, Moen posted to Facebook.
The story itself contains several hallmarks of being fake: an invented hospital; a dubious cause of death ("stomach pain") is followed by the contradictory claim that the cause of death was "not immediately known"; a quote from Donald Trump is not attributed to any source; a quote from the pastor T.D. Jakes is attributed to "local media" but no specific source is named.
HoustonChronicle-TV.com is not in any way associated with the Houston Chronicle newspaper.
candidates.description: A dubious web site falsely reported the death of the Christian Contemporary music artist Don Moen.

result.explanation: This assessment is evidence-based. The news caption stating that Pastor and Gospel Singer Don Moen is dead after a short illness is FALSE.  Snopes.com debunks this claim, stating it originated from a dubious website (HoustonChronicle-TV.com) and was confirmed as a hoax by Moen's collaborator and son. The article is riddled with inaccuracies, including a fake hospital and fabricated quotes. Don Moen himself refuted the death claim via social media on the same day the false report was published.
supporting_evidence: Source 1: Snopes.com fact-check on Don Moen's death hoax confirms that the claim is false and originated from a dubious website. It highlights inaccuracies in the false report, including a fake hospital and fabricated quotes. Moen's family and collaborators confirmed the hoax.

final_result.validation_summary: Internal check flags the caption as false. External check strongly supports this, citing a Snopes.com fact-check that debunks the death hoax.  The external evidence shows the claim originated from a dubious website and was confirmed false by Moen's family and associates.  There is complete agreement between internal and external validation that the caption is false and out of context.  The high confidence score reflects the strong external evidence supporting the false nature of the claim.  The internal entity recognition provides weak corroboration by flagging elements as being miscellaneous but the overall information suggests the claim is false.  The external validation provides highly confident evidence of falseness.  The two validations are completely consistent, leading to the high confidence score in the conclusion that the original caption is false and OOC (out of context).  There are no discrepancies between internal and external checks. The external check is a highly trusted source, offering detailed evidence and corroboration from Moen's family and team. Therefore the confidence score of 10 is justified. The combination of a solid internal check, indicating the caption is likely false, and the overwhelmingly strong external validation supporting this, with high confidence, leads to a high confidence in the final result.
